awd_titl_txt: EAGER/Collaborative Research: Demonstrating the Importance of Research Setting Representativeness in Systems Engineering and Design Research
awd_abstract_narration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) grant supports fundamental research into the factors that determine whether a research setting is sufficiently representative of real-world systems engineering and design situations. Designing complex engineering systems such as critical infrastructure, capital-intensive projects, and national defense systems involves large design teams consisting of hundreds to thousands of individuals over timescales reaching into decades. This project addresses the fundamental issue of understanding the design of such complex engineering systems using simpler, shorter-duration, and more controlled research settings. The research objective of this project is to explore the creation and validation of standards for research setting representativeness to assess whether and the extent to which findings from one research setting can be extend to others. If successful, this work will transform research in the community by enabling more efficient knowledge aggregation through a rigorous methodological foundation for assessing how well, and in what dimensions, research settings represent their real counterparts. This foundation will enrich empirical and theory-driven research within the systems engineering and design community by improving validity assessment of research outcomes across diverse methodological perspectives. As a crucial component of this project, results will be disseminated to diverse audience through presentations and workshops at community-specific conferences. Dissemination and community-building activities will foster an ongoing conversation around the need for shared standards and consensus for the kinds of knowledge to be gained from diverse research settings and methodological approaches. 

The core intellectual contributions of this high-risk high-reward work are to identify dimensions of research setting representativeness, understand how they impact design and execution of research studies, and demonstrate a methodology to generate insights regarding representativeness. Two pilot studies will probe varying dimensions of representativeness for a spacecraft design process. The first pilot study will compare the real spacecraft design process to a concurrent design environment with a smaller team working on a shorter timescale. The second pilot study will compare a fully abstracted function optimization game to a more representative game that models the context and technical dependencies of a spacecraft in the optimization problem. The pilot studies will demonstrate the viability of studying the effects of research setting representativeness on designer behaviors. The potential exists that research setting representativeness is impractical to characterize well, which is a principal risk factor for this project. However, the potential reward is equally high. If successful, results from this project are expected to provide the foundation of multi-method, multi-scale research, allowing researchers to interpret, evaluate, and build on each other?s results across different research methodologies. This would transform the research community and enable new discoveries that far exceed current research capabilities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Systems engineering and design (SE&D) researchers increasingly tackle questions at the intersection of technical and social aspects of complex systems design. Practical challenges of access, limited observation scope, and long timescales limit our ability to study SE&D phenomena in the real world. As a result, studies are typically conducted in model world settings, such as behavioral experiments with student subjects. Model worlds must be representative of the phenomena being studied to ensure insights generalize to the real-world settings. Currently, there is a lack of shared understanding and standards within the SE&D research community to describe the relevant dimensions and evaluate representativeness of model worlds.

 

To that end, this EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project aimed to generate new knowledge about research setting representativeness in the context of SE&D research, and support community building towards adopting the resulting standards. The work was conducted in three major thrusts. First, through a systematic literature review and series of community engagement workshops, we proposed a primary framework to describe and address "model world representativeness." We published a communication that defines the concept of model worlds, disambiguates representativeness from related concepts, draws comparisons to other research domains like economics and biology having similar challenges to empirical research, and suggests the critical dimensions for implementing model worlds in SE&D research.  

 

Second, the multi-institution team conducted three connected studies examining the phenomenon of design team communication across settings that varied in their model world implementation. We studied NASA concurrent design teams designing spacecraft, a college classroom-based experiment involving the design of an engine, and a computational multi-agent simulation of design teams solving the engine design problem. Each study answered a specific question about design team communication, but also served as a basis for reflecting on best practices on designing model worlds for SE&D research. For example, motivated by potential differences between professional spacecraft designers and college students, the multi-agent simulation investigated how agent expertise--encoded in differential decision policies based on domain knowledge and fixation--affects emergent design team behaviors. Results show more expert teams align communications with technical problems interdependencies and produce more effective solutions. The results have been disseminated to the SE&D research community through multiple journal papers.

 

Finally, we revisited the representativeness framework to provide more specific guidance by comparing experimental results of the three alternative model world implementations. Our resulting discussion highlights the complexity of the concept of representativeness. Although traditional research setting critiques tend to focus on particular model world dimensions (subjects, task, context), the interactions among them appear to be at least as important as applied to SE&D research. For example, student subjects can behave representatively if the task and context are appropriately calibrated to their knowledge and skills. We also found that representativeness is not tied to the model world, rather it depends on a) the research focus and b) the level of analysis pursued by the researcher. For example, the same model world may be well equipped to study the differences between levels of communication among team members but not the absolute amount of communication by any one designer.

 

These results emphasize the need to think carefully about representativeness in each research project and in the design or adoption of each model world, and provide a structured approach to incorporating representativeness considerations while designing SE&D research studies. The outcomes of this EAGER project will help in advancing further research and community discussions around these concepts. To that end, the workshops organized as part of this project seeded an interdisciplinary community of interested researchers to more deliberately describe and evaluate representativeness in SE&D research.
